qas.question: What is used to determine whether federal judicial power extends to formulating binding precedent?

answers.text: the act of deciding a case becomes a limited form of lawmaking in itself

qas.question: Why is stare decisis a limited form of lawmaking?

answers.text: an appellate court's rulings will thereby bind itself and lower courts in future cases

qas.question: Who else does stare decisis affect?

answers.text: impliedly binds all persons within the court's jurisdiction

qas.question: Formulating judicial power is done by following what rule?
What fraction of federal appellate cases were published in 2007?
When did federal appellate cases begin to be published?
What do decisions made by lower courts bind?

plausible_answers.text: all persons within the court's jurisdiction

qas.question: Who are unaffected by stare decisis?

context: The difficult question is whether federal judicial power extends to formulating binding precedent through strict adherence to the rule of <a0_0><b4_0>stare decisis<b4_0/><a0_0/>. This is where <a1_0>the act of deciding a case becomes a limited form of lawmaking in itself<a1_0/>, in that <a2_0><b7_0>an appellate court's rulings<b7_0/> will thereby bind itself and lower courts in future cases<a2_0/> (and therefore also <a3_0>impliedly binds <b8_0>all persons within the court's jurisdiction<b8_0/><a3_0/>). Prior to a major change to federal court rules in <b6_0>2007<b6_0/>, about <b5_0>one-fifth<b5_0/> of federal appellate cases were published and thereby became binding precedents, while the rest were unpublished and bound only the parties to each case.
